Alan Turing

The father of artificial intelligence and godfather of all modern computers

Here is a time line of Alan Turing's life:

  • 1912 - Born in Maida Vale, London.
  • 1936 - Published the paper "On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem" which later become known as "Turing's Proof", and introduced Turing Machines, that formed the concept of algorithms and computations for computer science.
  • 1938 - During the second World War, Turing was breaking German ciphers at Bletchley Park. He devised a machine called the Bombe to crack the German Enigma cipher machine.
  • 1942 - Devised a technique named Turingery that was used against the German Lorenz cipher messages.
  • 1946 - Was appointed an Officer of the Order of the British Empire(OBE) by King George VI for his wartime services.
  • 1950 - Wrote the paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence" that introduced the experiment known as the Turing test to see if artificial intelligence could exhibit intelligent behavior identical to a humans.
  • 1952 - Convicted for homosexuality which were criminal offenses in the United Kingdom during that time period, Turing was chemically castrated.
  • 1954 - Was found dead in his house and was believed that he commited suicide with cyanide poisoning.
  • 2009 - A petition was started by John Graham-Cumming who urged the British Government to apologise for Turing's prosecution as a homosexual. The petition was a success, and the Prime Minister released a statement apologising and stating that the treatment of Turing was "appalling."
  • 2013 - Queen Elizabeth II immediately signed a pardon for Turing's conviction on December 24, 2013.
  • 2014 - Queen Elizabeth II announced Turing was officially pardoned in August 22, 2014.
  • 2016 - The United Kingdom passed a new law termed the "Alan Turing law" which served as an amnesty to pardon men who were convicted for homosexual acts under historical legislation.

If you have time, you should read more about this incredible human being on his Wikipedia entry.
